abstract.text: An object that represents the configuration of a Virtio file system device.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use
to create a Virtio file system device which allows the host to expose directories to a guest using a
label.
The example below shows the creation of a
that shares a single directory that the user can manually mount after creating a mount point in the guest VM:

code: // Define a URL to a specific file path, in this case the
// "Projects" directory in the user's home directory.
let sharedDirectory = VZSharedDirectory(url: projectsURL, readOnly: false)
// Create the VZVirtioFileSystemDeviceConfiguration and assign it a unique tag.
// Define a URL to a specific file path, in this case the
// "Projects" directory in the user's home directory.
// Create the VZVirtioFileSystemDeviceConfiguration and assign it a unique tag.

inlineContent.text: A
can also share multiple directories. The example below demonstrates sharing the
and
directories from the user’s home directory to the guest VM:

code: // Define URLs at specific file paths, in this case the
// "Projects" and "Invoices" directories in the user's home directory.
let sharedProjectsDirectory = VZSharedDirectory(url: projectsURL, readOnly: false)
// It's also possible to share directories that are read-only:
let sharedInvoicesDirectory = VZSharedDirectory(url: invoicesURL, readOnly: true)
// Associate each shared directory with a name, which is how the framework lists them under the mount point.
// Create the VZVirtioFileSystemDeviceConfiguration and assign it a unique tag.
// Define URLs at specific file paths, in this case the
// "Projects" and "Invoices" directories in the user's home directory.
// It's also possible to share directories that are read-only:
// Associate each shared directory with a name, which is how the framework lists them under the mount point.
// Create the VZVirtioFileSystemDeviceConfiguration and assign it a unique tag.

inlineContent.text: The commands required to mount shared directories in a guest VM aren’t commands that your app can execute or that you can script from inside your application to a VM; the user must perform them either interactively or as part of a script while logged in to the guest. You must communicate these requirements to the user of your app.
Mounting a shared directory requires the user to execute a command in a terminal window, the specific mount command depends on the guest VM’s operating system:
In macOS guests, use
In Linux guests, use
The
argument is the file system device configuration label —
in the single directory case and
in the multiple directory case in these examples — and
is the mount point in the guest file system to which the framework attaches the shared directories.

content.text: Automounting shared directories in macOS VMs

inlineContent.text: In macOS 13 and later, it’s possible to specify a file system device that macOS 13 or later guest VMs automount using the
property. The example below demonstrates sharing a single macOS directory, to a macOS guest:

code: // Define a URL to a specific file path, in this case the
// "Projects" directory in the user's home directory.
let sharedDirectory = VZSharedDirectory(url: projectsURL, readOnly: false)
// Assign the automount tag to this share. macOS shares automounted directories automatically under /Volumes in the guest.

inlineContent.text: The macOS guest automounts the user’s
directory from the host and shares it under
in the macOS guest.
It’s also possible to automount multiple directories in macOS guests. The example below demonstrates sharing the
and
directories from the user’s home directory to the macOS guest VM:

code: // Define URLs at specific file paths, in this case the
// "Projects" and "Invoices" directories in the user's home directory.
// Share the contents of ~/Projects, which is writeable.
let sharedProjectsDirectory = VZSharedDirectory(url: projectsURL, readOnly: false)
// Share the contents of ~/Invoices, but make it read only.
let sharedInvoicesDirectory = VZSharedDirectory(url: invoicesURL, readOnly: true)
// Associate each shared directory with a name, which is how the framework lists them under the mount point in the guest.
// Assign the automount tag to this share. macOS will automatically mount each shared directory at /Volumes/My Shared Files.

inlineContent.text: In the guest, the framework lists each shared directory by its specified name under
. Here, the shared directories in the macOS guest are
and

abstract.text: Create virtual machines and run macOS and Linux-based operating systems.
The base class for a directory sharing device configuration.
The Linux directory share for Rosetta.
An object that describes a directory share for multiple directories.
An object that defines the directory share for a single directory.
An object that represents the configuration of a Virtio file system device.
Creates a configuration for a VIRTIO file system device.
A value that indicates that the guest needs to automount this file system device in the guest VM.
A value that defines how the host exposes resources to the guest virtual machine.
A label that identifies this device in the guest VM.
Checks to see whether a Virtio tag is valid.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
